key_points: Derek Chauvin, former Minneapolis police officer, pleaded guilty to federal civil rights violations involving George Floyd and a minor.
Chauvin admitted to willfully depriving George Floyd of his constitutional rights, resulting in Floyd's bodily injury and death.
The plea includes Chauvin admitting to using unreasonable and excessive force against Floyd, violating Minneapolis Police Department policy.
Chauvin also pleaded guilty to violating a 14-year-old juvenile's constitutional rights in 2017, involving use of excessive force.
Attorney General Merrick B. Garland emphasized the commitment to holding those who violate the Constitution accountable.
Chauvin admitted to not rendering medical aid to Floyd, which contributed to Floyd's death.
In the 2017 case, Chauvin admitted to holding the juvenile by the throat and striking him with a flashlight.
The plea agreement suggests a sentencing range of 20-25 years in federal custody for Chauvin.
Chauvin will not be eligible to work in any law enforcement capacity after his release from federal custody.

The case was investigated by the FBI and the Minnesota Bureau of Criminal Apprehension, and prosecuted by a team from the Civil Rights Division and U.S. Attorney's Office for the District of Minnesota.
spokespersons: Samantha Trepel (Special Litigation Counsel, Civil Rights Division)
Tara Allison (Trial Attorney, Civil Rights Division)
